msItem.author: Ps.-WILLIAM OF AUVERGNE
msItem.title: Super Apocalypsim
msItem.incipit: Apocalipsis id est reuelatio Ihesu Christi a Iesu Christo facta hec supplere Non a me. In hoc uitat Iohannes arroganciam quia non suam sed Christi Ihesu dicit apocalipsim
msItem.explicit: et corrigat quicquid uiderit corrigendus amen
msItem.note: Marginal guides and alphabetical letters. unpr.; the unique copy of William of Auvergne, according to Stegmüller, Bibl. 2805. Glorieux, Théol. 141aa, considers the ascription dubious or false, and the work is not listed by Ottmann.

Followed by two alphabetical subject-indexes in 2 cols, fols. 166–70, 170v-3; fols. 173v-4v blank. The first index, which is keyed to the marginal alphabetical letters, ends with an elaborate explanation of its use.

supportDesc.collation: 1–58, 66 / 7–228; catchwords; quire-signatures of the usual late medieval form.

layoutDesc.layout: Frame-ruled with crayon; written in c. 30 long lines.

handDesc.handNote: A single practised Continental scribe, writing cursive, except for fols. 170v-3, added in a rough secretary hand, c. 1500. The same hand, almost certainly Hammond Haydok’s, wrote the index on fols. ii-iii of MS 48, and the list on fol. ivvof MS 189. At the foot of fol. 170 is a note by the main scribe: ‘quat’ – prec. 1d ob / - script’ 13 d’.

decoDesc.decoNote: Blue initials flourished in red. The running heads are accompanied by red or blue paraphs.

binding.p: s. xv, heavily restored in modern times; cushion-bevelled oak boards with slightly projecting squares, now bare, rebacked with modern vellum; sewn on five bands. Two straps from recesses in the front board to pins in the back, all gone. Chain-staples formerly near the foot of the foredge of the front board, and in the middle of the foot of the back board. No flyleaves or pastedowns.

history.provenance: At the end of art. 1 on fol. 46 the scribe has written ‘Magister Hamound’. This could be Hammond Haydok (for whom see MS 16), and would suggest that the book was made for him.

At the College by c. 1500, certainly by 1556: UO65. 175. At the head of fol. 1 is the James no. ‘235’, s. xvii. Inside the front board is a sheet of paper, with a table of contents and ‘N. 4. 3. Art:’, s. xvii, canc. and replaced with ‘C. 1. 3 (XLII)’, in red; the College bookplate. ‘3’ is inked on the foredge.
